title: Can I garnish wages of judgment debtor's spouse?
question: In 2006, loaned money to ex to buy a house. Got a judgment for the loan and put a lien on his property. Then he remarried and added his new wife to house as community property (cal). He has NO income - she has a job and pays all of the bills. Is there anyway I can collect against the spouse? Do I need to file a small claims against the two of them?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Spousal debt,Marriage
answers:
The earnings of a married person during marriage are not liable for a debt incurred by the person's spouse before marriage. After the earnings of the married person are paid, they remain not liable so long as they are held in a deposit account in which the person's spouse has no right of withdrawal and are uncommingled with other property in the community estate, except property insignificant in amount.

I recommend you contact local counsel to discuss the specific facts of your case to help you navigate the collections and community property laws that intersect in your case.
